context: Kinetics Furthermore, one batch experiment performed in the SBR process during phase 1 (day 39) was selected to verify whether the model adequately described the observed trends during one cycle of running. Experimental and simulated results of VOC liquid concentrations and Oxygen Uptake Rate are plotted in Fig. 4 . Only B, T, E, X were injected in this batch test. Benzene, toluene, ethylbenzene and p-xylene were quickly removed from liquid phase, and their removal fractions were 99.93%, 99.91%, 99.93% and 99.75% respectively within 2 h (Fig. 4(a)). BTEX removal fractions within 2 h calculated from model outputs were respectively: 99.89%, 99.95%, 99.95% and 99.93%. The resulting model outputs (BTEX elimination kinetics and OUR) were in accordance with the experimental data. The experimental OUR curve (after subtracting endogenous activity) indicates a relatively small oxygen consumption of about 3.99 mgO2 L−1, showing that BTEX (total concentration of 207.2 mgCOD L−1) were poorly biodegraded here (Fig. 4(b)).

llm_generation.summary: In this context, ethylbenzene and p-xylene are both volatile organic compounds (VOCs) included in a batch experiment assessing their removal from liquid phases in a sequencing batch reactor (SBR) process. The study reports high removal efficiencies for both compounds, indicating their similar behavior in the treatment process. However, the specific interactions or comparative significance between ethylbenzene and p-xylene are not elaborated upon beyond their inclusion in the same experimental setup.
llm_generation.reason: The score of 3 reflects a moderate relevance, as both ethylbenzene and p-xylene are part of the same experimental study focusing on VOC removal. Their removal efficiencies are reported, but there is no detailed discussion of their specific interactions or unique roles in the process.
